text: I've spent the last 20 years raising
funds and awareness for breast cancer
and the reason I got so involved is that
when I started working for the ester
Lauder companies they just started their
breast cancer awareness campaign and the
founder Evelyn Lauder asked me to help
her with a new campaign she had and I
said of course what is it I just said
well it's breast cancer Elizabeth
because I think that women all over the
world are dying of breast cancer and
nobody's talking about it and when she
said that I realized that that's very
much the experience that my family had
gone through with my grandmother who had
just died of breast cancer because at
the time it was just a subject which we
didn't talk about the pink ribbon hadn't
been invented magazine covers didn't
talk about breast cancer they would
never been a show like your show where
we sat here talking about breast cancer
and we didn't know anything about it and
when my grandmother found her lump she
was in her late 70s by then she was so
embarrassed and frightened she didn't
tell anybody for a few years so by the
time she did finally pluck up courage to
tell her doctor way before she told her
family it had got it had progressed to a
stage where it wasn't really treatable
and it was very very sad so when Evelyn
Lauder told me about her campaign I
joined in and I have to say over the
last 20 years there's been the most
phenomenal breakthrough in awareness for
breast cancer but and in the treatments
and in the diagnosis there's been a
great improvement but obviously there's
still a great way to go and how did it
make you feel that it wasn't talked
about in your family because as I say
that was a common experience but
obviously if it's not talked about you
can't help that person and then in
hindsight it can lead to regret I feel
sadder and sadder in hindsight
especially now you know we have this
wonderful book called afterwards this
year which is breast cancer survivors
and people going through treatment
talking about their experiences and what
they're going through and I just wish so
much that we'd known all that when my
grandmother was ill and suffering and
scared
I wish we've been able to talk about all
the things that we do talk about now and
you know we hear from survivors and they
for some people it it really helps them
a lot to know they're not alone to hear
what other people are going through and
to discuss different ways that they can
deal with the very traumatic things
they're going through and there wasn't
that help 20 years ago so we have moved
a huge way forward but um we're just
still concern now that more women more
people join in and can be heard and can
listen to what other people have to say
as well as of course we're still telling
people about the disease if they don't
yet know much about it and also of
course as it happens also of course a
very important thing
raising funds still so that one day
there will be a time when there is no
more breast cancer
